Market Summary
‚Ä¢ BTC slid into the $77k‚Äì$79k zone, with thin order books making long wicks and abrupt swings more likely.
‚Ä¢ The latest drop looks easier to explain by derivatives liquidations than by strong spot conviction selling.
‚Ä¢ In a weak-flow market, rallies tend to be short-covering led, so upside remains heavy unless spot demand returns.
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúEverything becomes a dump catalyst‚Äù is typical when positioning is being unwound and liquidity is scarce.
‚Ä¢ Cross-asset stress (including sharp moves in metals) reinforces the risk of forced selling and margin pressure spilling into crypto.
‚Ä¢ Government shutdown headlines keep uncertainty elevated and can raise volatility across all risk assets.
‚Ä¢ Conclusion: This is not a ‚Äúcall-the-bottom‚Äù phase. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúconfirm the flush + watch flows‚Äù phase.

On-Chain & Technical Trend
‚Ä¢ Large liquidation days often cleanse excess leverage, but if open interest rebuilds too quickly, the next squeeze/liquidation risk rises again.
‚Ä¢ For BTC, the first technical hurdle is reclaiming and holding $80k. Failure tends to invite another liquidity sweep.
‚Ä¢ ETH saw heavy long liquidations; a short-term rebound is possible if funding/OI stabilize, but the quality of the rebound matters (spot support vs. pure derivatives).
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúIt fell a lot‚Äù is not a signal by itself. Confirmation should come from volume and flows (ETF / stablecoin / spot).
‚Ä¢ Conclusion: Leverage alone cannot create a sustainable uptrend. The recovery condition is ‚Äúflow reversal + healthier OI structure.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ As long liquidations stay dominant, participants remain defensive and rallies tend to fade quickly.

Bitcoin $BTC   sliding to its lowest level since 2024 feels brutal, but historically, this is the phase where long-term fortunes are quietly built. Bear markets strip away hype, leverage, and weak conviction, leaving price driven more by fundamentals than noise. While fear dominates headlines, experienced investors know that extreme pessimism often signals that much of the selling pressure is already behind the market.  The most effective bear-market strategy isn‚Äôt trying to catch the exact bottom it‚Äôs risk control and patience. Dollar-cost averaging into high-conviction assets, keeping cash reserves, and avoiding excessive leverage help traders survive volatility. This is also the period to rotate from speculation into quality: strong networks, healthy balance sheets, and real adoption tend to outperform once conditions stabilize.  Finally, bear markets are as much psychological as they are financial. The winners are usually those who stay disciplined, continue learning, and prepare for the next cycle while others disengage. History shows that Bitcoin‚Äôs $BTC   deepest drawdowns often precede its strongest recoveries. The key question isn‚Äôt whether prices look ugly today but whether you‚Äôre positioned for when sentiment eventually flips. $ETH

Crypto ‚ÄòExtreme Fear‚Äô Could Signal a Rebound, Says Santiment   The Crypto Fear & Greed #Index  dropped to a score of 18, the lowest reading in 2026 and the first time it reached that level since Dec. 19. By Saturday, the index rebounded slightly to 20, still firmly in Extreme Fear territory. The index had been in Fear since Jan. 20 before sliding into Extreme Fear on Thursday.   Analytics platform Santiment flagged the current wave of negativity as one of the few #bullish  signals available right now. The firm noted that the ratio of bearish to bullish comments on social media is heavily skewed toward fear, which historically precedes a price reversal.   $BTC  is trading at $76,250 after falling nearly 10% over the past seven days. $ETH  has declined more than 17% during the same period, now sitting at $2,290. Both assets have been under sustained selling pressure since mid-January.   $BTC  has not closed above the $100,000 mark since Nov. 13. The prolonged consolidation below that level has prompted some analysts to question whether the broader #crypto  market has entered a bear phase, though Santiment's data suggests otherwise.   Crypto analyst Benjamin Cowen addressed expectations of a large rotation from gold and silver into #cryptocurrency  during a video on Thursday. He stated that such a rotation into $BTC  is "probably not going to happen" in the short term, pushing back against a widely held assumption in the market.   Coinbase chief business officer Shan Aggarwal took a different view, posting on X that the current downturn is "just a blip." Aggarwal pointed to traditional financial institutions like MasterCard, PayPal, American Express, and JPMorgan actively posting #crypto-related  job listings as a sign that institutional interest remains intact.   Bitwise CEO Huntley Horsley echoed a similar stance on the same day, stating the space is moving toward the #mainstream.

$BTC  Drops Out of Global Top 10 Assets by Market Cap    $BTC 's market #capitalization  has fallen to approximately $1.57 trillion, placing it 13th among global assets. The drop came after its price declined sharply from around $90,000 to $78,500 over the past seven days, a loss of more than 11%. Saudi Aramco and Tesla now rank above $BTC  by this metric.   During October's all-time high, $BTC  briefly traded above $126,000 and approached a $2.5 trillion valuation. At that point, it held the seventh position among global assets and had previously entered the top five, surpassing companies like Google and Amazon.   The sell-off was partly driven by a surge in U.S. dollar strength following President Trump's nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next #FederalReserve  chair. Warsh is known for favoring higher real interest rates and a smaller Fed balance sheet, and his appointment triggered the dollar's biggest rally since May.   The dollar rally pulled #down  not only $BTC  but also precious metals. Gold plunged 9% in a single trading session to just under $4,900, while silver dropped 26.3% to $85.3. Despite the drawdown, gold remains the largest asset globally by market cap at $34.1 trillion, followed by silver at $4.8 trillion.   $ETH  also took a significant hit during this period, falling to 56th place among global assets with a market cap just above $300 billion. Ethereum lost 14.5% of its value in a single week, pushing it below companies like Caterpillar, Coca-Cola, and Cisco by #marketcap .   The broader #crypto  market lost roughly 6% in 24 hours, with total market capitalization dropping from about $3.1 trillion to around $2.6 trillion. The decline triggered $1.8 billion in liquidations across crypto markets, the largest single-day event since October.

Peruvian Sol to USD Exchange  The exchange rate between the Peruvian Sol and the US Dollar changes depending on the method used. Cash withdrawals, card payments, online transfers, and digital platforms all have different pricing, which can lead to differences in the final amount received. Even small gaps can result in significant losses for larger conversions.  How much does the rate vary?  The Sol to USD rate typically varies between one and eight percent. The mid market rate reflects the true rate without markups and serves as a reference.  Why are cash withdrawals expensive?  Cash withdrawals include multiple fees from banks, ATMs, and card networks, such as foreign transaction, ATM, and network fees, plus exchange rate markups. Withdrawing larger amounts less often and declining optional conversions can reduce costs.  Why are online transfers and cards cheaper?  Online transfers offer better rates due to lower overhead and high transaction volumes. Card payments sit between cash and online rates, depending on fees and conversion handling. Paying in local currency is usually cheaper.  Where can rates be compared?  Rates can be compared on platforms like Bitget, Wise, Xe, Google Finance, Coinbase, Kraken, and Binance, which offer real-time pricing, charts, and conversion tools for digital or fiat transactions.  Conclusion  Sol to USD rates vary by method. Cash withdrawals are most expensive, while online transfers and stablecoins are closest to the mid market. Comparing providers and fees helps avoid losses.  FAQ  What is the rate based on? Supply and demand and economic conditions. Should I exchange money before traveling? Exchange small amounts and use cards or digital methods. Is it better to pay in Sol or USD? Paying in Sol usually gives better rates. Are digital conversions legal? Yes, follow local regulations. Ethereum Under Pressure: What‚Äôs Really Driving the Recent Drop  #Ethereum ‚Äôs recent drop isn‚Äôt the result of a bad headline, but an outcome of several pressures hitting the market at the same time.  First, large institutional holders have been forced to sell. Some companies that hold massive amounts of ETH had borrowed against those holdings. As prices fell, lenders demanded repayments, which led to forced $ETH  sales. When big players unload coins quickly, especially during low-liquidity periods, prices tend to slide faster than usual.  Second, the broader financial environment isn‚Äôt helping. Money is being pulled out of risk assets as U.S. liquidity tightens. Investors are shifting toward safer places like cash or #gold , and #crypto  funds have seen notable outflows. Even Ethereum ETFs have lost assets recently, showing that demand from traditional investors has cooled.  Finally, the charts turned against ETH. The price broke below the key $2,300 support, triggering selling from short-term traders. While this move pushed ETH into oversold territory, a sign that selling may slow down, confidence won‚Äôt return unless that level is reclaimed.  The bigger picture? This looks more like a reset than a collapse. Ethereum needs to hold the $2,224 support zone to avoid deeper losses. If buyers step in there, a short-term bounce is possible. If not, the market may need more time to stabilize.

OpenSea has added support for web3:// (ERC-4804)

Most NFTs today still rely on off-chain infrastructure to be accessed and understood.
When those access layers disappear, the asset itself becomes unreachable.

ERC-4804 introduces a native way to resolve NFT metadata directly from Ethereum ‚Äî removing reliance on gateways, DNS, or centralized access points.
This standard was originally proposed and advanced by the QuarkChain team to address this long-standing gap in Web3.

For QuarkChain, this aligns directly with the Super World Computer vision:
a system where decentralization extends beyond execution to include how applications and data are accessed ‚Äî forming a truly end-to-end decentralized stack.
